turns.content:
As a kid growing up in the Bay Area, I was fortunate enough to have the resources and support to learn and excel at chess. By the time I was 16, I had achieved the title of International Master. But it wasn't just about the personal accomplishment for me – I wanted to share my love for the game with others and inspire them to learn as well.

I started teaching chess to elementary school students at my local community center and quickly realized the importance of community building. It wasn't just about teaching them the rules and strategies of the game – it was about creating a safe and supportive space where they could learn, grow, and have fun.

As the pandemic hit, I shifted my focus to helping teens cope with the challenges of remote learning and isolation through the organization 7 Cups. I spent over 150 hours as a listener, supporting them through mental health issues and providing a listening ear during difficult times. Through this experience, I learned even more about the importance of community and the crucial role it plays in supporting individuals and helping them thrive.

In parallel to my community building efforts, I also discovered a passion for computer science. I was drawn to the field because of its potential to solve real-world problems and make a positive impact in society. I took a variety of courses at community college and completed a mobile development internship, where I learned about the development process and how to build polished products.

Now, as I prepare to transfer to the University, I am excited to use my community building skills and technical expertise to make a positive impact on campus. I hope to continue to learn and grow as a computer scientist, and eventually use my skills to tackle some of the most pressing issues facing our society, such as improving access to mental health resources and addressing social inequality.
Great start, make these few changes: write more about what he did in his internship, use examples of how he can help at the university, write at least 1000 words

As a privileged international chess master, I have had the resources and opportunities to develop my skills and become a top player. However, I didn't want to keep these advantages to myself. I wanted to inspire and teach others, particularly those from underprivileged communities, to learn and excel in chess. I began volunteering as a chess coach at a local after-school program, and it was there that I realized the importance of community building and supporting each other.

During the pandemic, I joined 7 Cups, a counseling organization, where I worked with teens struggling with mental health issues. Through my conversations with them, I learned how to provide emotional support and how to listen actively. I also took online classes in psychology and read books on different psychotherapies to better understand the challenges my clients were facing. I mentored other volunteers and taught them how to provide support to others.

As I continued to volunteer and learn, I realized that I wanted to use my skills and knowledge to create solutions to real-world problems. That's when I decided to pursue a degree in computer science. I enrolled in community college and took several computer science courses, including Data Science, where I used Python libraries to perform data analysis, and Assembly, where I learned how code is executed on a CPU. I also completed an internship at a tech company, where I worked on a web development project and learned about programmatic collaboration and agile development.

Now, as I prepare to transfer to the university, I am excited to use my community-building skills and technical knowledge to make a positive impact on campus. I plan on joining clubs and organizations that focus on social justice and community service, and using my skills in computer science to build solutions to help others. For example, I could use my data analysis skills to support a mental health organization and create a platform for teens to connect with mental health

Make these changes but keep everything else: talk about how he had access to great coaches and learned a ton of Chess strategies on the internet, similarly, he learned a ton on the internet about software engineering. Include more of his software engineering experience as well

As a kid, I was lucky to have access to great chess coaches and a wealth of information on the internet to learn strategies and techniques. This allowed me to eventually reach the title of international master. But it wasn't just about the accolades for me. I wanted to use my passion for chess to inspire and teach others. I started volunteering at local schools and community centers, teaching kids the game and showing them the benefits of strategic thinking and problem-solving.

In addition to teaching chess, I also found myself drawn to helping others. I became a volunteer for 7 Cups, a counseling organization that connects people in need with trained listeners. As a listener, I provided support to teens struggling with mental health issues, especially during the pandemic. This experience taught me the importance of community-building and the impact it can have on individuals and society as a whole.

As I continued to learn and grow, I became interested in computer science. I saw it as a way to use my skills to build solutions to real-world problems. I took advanced placement computer science in high school and continued my studies in community college, where I took courses in data science and assembly language. I also interned at a mobile development company, where I gained hands-on experience in building web applications.

Now, as I prepare to transfer to the university, I am excited to continue my studies in computer science and use my skills to make a positive impact on campus and in the wider community. I plan to use my community-building skills to connect with fellow students and work together on projects that benefit the university and society. I also hope to continue learning and expanding my knowledge in computer science, so that I can develop solutions to some of the most pressing problems facing our world today.

In short, my diverse experiences in chess, mental health, and computer science have given me a unique perspective and set of skills that I believe make me a strong candidate for the university's computer science program. I am passionate about using these skills to make a positive impact on the world and I am excited to continue learning and growing at the university.

Keep everything but touch on how he has solved hard problems (like being an international master in chess) and how he will bring this rigor along with his community building skills to greatly improve the campus

Growing up, I was lucky to have access to some of the best chess coaches and resources available. I spent hours on end studying different strategies, pouring over games from some of the greatest players in history, and practicing my own skills. My dedication paid off and I eventually earned the title of International Master.

But becoming an International Master wasn't just about my own personal success. I knew that I had been given a great privilege in being able to learn and grow in the game of chess, and I wanted to give back to my community. I began volunteering as a chess coach, teaching kids and inspiring them to reach their full potential. Through this experience, I learned the importance of community building and working together to achieve a common goal.

In addition to my work as a chess coach, I also volunteered with 7 Cups, a counseling organization that helps teens struggling with mental health issues. The pandemic has only amplified the need for mental health support, and I was proud to be able to help in any way I could. I connected with teens as a listener, providing support and guidance during difficult times. This experience taught me the importance of empathy and understanding, and how even the smallest gestures can make a big difference in someone's life.

As I began to explore my interests in college, I found myself drawn to the field of computer science. I was fascinated by the potential for CS to solve real-world problems and make a positive impact on society. I enrolled in a series of challenging courses, and even completed an internship in mobile development, where I learned the ins and outs of building polished and user-friendly apps. I also participated in hackathons, where I was able to put my skills to the test and work on projects that I was passionate about.

Now, as I prepare to transfer to the university, I am excited to bring all of these experiences and skills to campus. I know that I have a lot to offer, and I am eager to use my knowledge of chess and my community-building skills to make a positive impact at the university. I am also looking forward to continuing my studies in computer science, where I know I will be able to solve even more complex and pressing problems.

I am confident that my background and experiences have prepared me well for success at the university. I am ready to hit the ground running and make the most of every opportunity that comes my way. I am excited to be a part of the university community, and I am determined to make a positive difference in any way that I can.
Keep everything but change the ending to focus on how he will continue to use his privilege to improve the quality of life for those less privileged

I have always been grateful for the privilege that has allowed me to pursue my passions and interests. Growing up, I had access to great coaches and resources that helped me become an international master in chess. I was able to learn from the best players in the world and develop strategies that helped me succeed in competitive tournaments.

But as I progressed in my chess career, I realized that my privilege also gave me a responsibility to give back to my community. I took on the role of a coach and mentor for younger players, and I was able to see the impact that my guidance had on their growth and development. I learned the importance of community-building and how it can help individuals achieve their goals and dreams.

I continued to apply these principles in my work with 7 cups, an organization that provides mental health support to teenagers. As a volunteer, I spent over 150 hours connecting with teens and supporting them through difficult times. I learned about the different mental illnesses and psychotherapies that can help individuals cope with their struggles. I also mentored other volunteers and taught them how to provide support to those in need.

In addition to my community-building skills, I have also pursued my passion for solving real-world problems through my studies in computer science. I took AP Computer Science and several courses at a community college that allowed me to explore the depths and complexity of the field. I also gained practical experience through an internship where I learned about software development and the different frameworks that are used to build applications.

I plan on using all of these skills and experiences to make a positive impact at the university. As a computer science student, I will bring my passion for solving problems and my community-building skills to the campus. I will work on projects that address pressing issues in society and strive to make a difference in the lives of others. I will continue to use my privilege to help those who are less fortunate and work towards creating a better world for everyone.
